#physics 
> [[Game Physics Research Hub|Game Physics Research Hub]]

So far in [[Velocities of Separation and Approach (Closing Velocity)|Velocities of Separation and Approach (Closing Velocity)]] we were using the offset between the two objects to determine the speed at which they were approaching or separating from each other. But in collisions this is different.

The **Contact Normal** is the direction in which to objects are colliding. This is also sometimes called the **Collision Normal**. 

This is different from the direction of the object centers in many cases:
![Pasted image 20221019122314.png](data:image/png;base64,)

But in the case of particles it is just the direction of object centers.
$$
\hat{n} = \widehat{(p_{a}-p_{b})}
$$
Which is why we saw that initially in [[Velocities of Separation and Approach (Closing Velocity)|Velocities of Separation and Approach (Closing Velocity)]].
This concept gets more important with Rigid Bodies.

By convention we always do the contact normal from object $a$'s perspective.

[source](https://learning.oreilly.com/library/view/game-physics-engine/9780123819765/chapter-52.html#:-:text=The%20Collision%20Direction%20and%20the%20Contact%20Normal)
